Line 15: Line 15:  
The concept of ''love'' is not amenable to one authoritative definition. It is the subject of considerable debate, enduring speculation, and thoughtful introspection. As an approximation, different aspects of ''love'' can be illustrated by comparing its corollaries and opposites. As a general expression of positive sentiment (a stronger form of ''like''), love is commonly contrasted with [[hate]] (or neutral [[apathy]]); as a less [[selfish|self-centered]] and more "mutual" sign of intense desire, love is commonly contrasted with [[lust]]; and as an interpersonal relationship with romantic overtones, love is commonly contrasted with [[friendship]], although other connotations
 
The concept of ''love'' is not amenable to one authoritative definition. It is the subject of considerable debate, enduring speculation, and thoughtful introspection. As an approximation, different aspects of ''love'' can be illustrated by comparing its corollaries and opposites. As a general expression of positive sentiment (a stronger form of ''like''), love is commonly contrasted with [[hate]] (or neutral [[apathy]]); as a less [[selfish|self-centered]] and more "mutual" sign of intense desire, love is commonly contrasted with [[lust]]; and as an interpersonal relationship with romantic overtones, love is commonly contrasted with [[friendship]], although other connotations
 
<br/>of ''love'' may be applied to close friendships as well.
 
<br/>of ''love'' may be applied to close friendships as well.
  +   +
[ily tjco & baby kades;]
     
The diverse range of meanings associated with the English word contrasts with the plurality of [[Greek words for love]], reflecting the depth, versatility, and complexity of the concept. This diversity of meanings is reflected in the many distinct classifications of love including [[romantic love]]; [[human sexuality|sexual]] desire; [[platonic love]]; [[love (religious views)|religious love]]; [[familial love]]; [[true love]]; and the more casual application of the term to anything pleasurable, enjoyable, desirable, or preferred, including activities and favorite foods.<ref name="IdiomNote">Casual application of the word "love" also includes [[idiom]]atic expressions and uses with differing connotations. For example, as a sardonic expression of disapproval: ''I just love how politicians always make empty promises.''</ref>
 
The diverse range of meanings associated with the English word contrasts with the plurality of [[Greek words for love]], reflecting the depth, versatility, and complexity of the concept. This diversity of meanings is reflected in the many distinct classifications of love including [[romantic love]]; [[human sexuality|sexual]] desire; [[platonic love]]; [[love (religious views)|religious love]]; [[familial love]]; [[true love]]; and the more casual application of the term to anything pleasurable, enjoyable, desirable, or preferred, including activities and favorite foods.<ref name="IdiomNote">Casual application of the word "love" also includes [[idiom]]atic expressions and uses with differing connotations. For example, as a sardonic expression of disapproval: ''I just love how politicians always make empty promises.''</ref>
Line 25: Line 27:      
Cultural differences make any universal definition of love difficult to establish. Expressions of love may include the love for a [[soul]] or [[mind]], the love of laws and organizations, love for a body, love for nature, love of food, love of money, love for learning, love of power, love of fame, love for the respect of others, etc. Different people place varying degrees of importance on the kinds of love they receive. Love is essentially an [[abstraction|abstract]] concept, easier to experience than to explain. Because of the complex and abstract nature of love, discourse on love is commonly reduced to a [[thought-terminating cliché]], and there are a number of common [[proverb]]s regarding love, from Virgil's "Love conquers all" to [[The Beatles]]' "[[All You Need is Love|All you need is love]]." [[Bertrand Russell]] describes love as a condition of "absolute value," as opposed to [[relative value]].
 
Cultural differences make any universal definition of love difficult to establish. Expressions of love may include the love for a [[soul]] or [[mind]], the love of laws and organizations, love for a body, love for nature, love of food, love of money, love for learning, love of power, love of fame, love for the respect of others, etc. Different people place varying degrees of importance on the kinds of love they receive. Love is essentially an [[abstraction|abstract]] concept, easier to experience than to explain. Because of the complex and abstract nature of love, discourse on love is commonly reduced to a [[thought-terminating cliché]], and there are a number of common [[proverb]]s regarding love, from Virgil's "Love conquers all" to [[The Beatles]]' "[[All You Need is Love|All you need is love]]." [[Bertrand Russell]] describes love as a condition of "absolute value," as opposed to [[relative value]].
